fields.title: Formation and early evolution of massive stars
fields.text:
The Netherlands Research School for Astronomy (NOVA), as part of its research program Formation and evolution of stars and planetary systems, plans to start a PhD project at the University of Amsterdam focused on the formation and early evolution of the most massive stars.

The mechanism by which the most massive stars form is poorly understood. Even though they are the most luminous objects in the Galaxy, their formation process and early evolution are obscured from view due to the tens to hundreds of magnitudes of (visual) extinction. Near-infrared imaging and spectroscopic surveys of high-mass star-forming regions reveal an amazingly complex interplay between the star formation process and the environment. K-band spectroscopy has resulted in the identification of young OB-type stars deeply embedded in (ultra-)compact H II regions, some of them still surrounded by a remnant accretion disk.

The key questions are: How are the most massive stars formed? What are the physical properties of the newly formed stars (photospheric parameters, rotational characteristics, radiation-driven wind, remnant accretion disks, binarity)? What is causing the lifetime problem (100x more UCHIIs than predicted by the current star formation rate)? Is the observed large range in spectral/photometric properties due to just a difference in mass (thus timescale), and/or does the environment play an important role?

Our strategy will be to extend the covered wavelength range of the many candidate young massive stars in our large survey down from the near-infrared into the optical (red) domain, thereby directly probing the stellar photosphere and wind. Optical/nIR spectra will be obtained within the VLT/X-shooter GTO program.  With VLT/CRIRES the CO bandhead emission will be studied at high spectral resolution, allowing detailed modeling of the remnant accretion disk around the massive YSOs. A study of several star-forming regions has been carried out with VLT/SINFONI and Spitzer, to obtain a full census of their stellar content, ionized material, and outflows. One of the goals of the project is to relate the found results to observations obtained at longer wavelengths (e.g. VLA, ALMA) that likely probe an even earlier phase in the star formation process. Reduction, analysis, and interpretation of the obtained data, including the collection of new data, will form a major part of the project that should lead to a PhD at the University of Amsterdam.  The position is offered for a period of 4 years and should be taken up in the Fall of 2009. The salary will be on the standard Dutch university scale.

Review of the applications will start on September 7, 2009, and continue until the position is filled.

fields.title: The structure of the stellar winds in AGB stars
fields.text:
Unravelling the physical and chemical structure of the stellar winds in AGB stars

A PhD position is available at the Astronomy Institute in Amsterdam, for research on the physical and chemical structure of the stellar winds in AGB stars.

Background

The late stages of stellar evolution of low- and intermediate-mass stars on the Asymptotic Giant Branch (AGB) are characterized by prodigious mass loss via a molecular, dusty wind. These winds dominate the final phases of the star and are important in the cycle of mass in galaxies. Understanding these stellar winds, their chemistry and time variation is one of the challenges of present-day AGB research. Recent observational studies of the mass loss history of AGB stars using both dust and gas give puzzling results, that suggest that the structure of these winds is not understood. For instance, the dust which condenses in the outflow is believed to be important in driving the stellar wind, but at present there is no good understanding of the importance of dust in driving oxygen-rich outflows. A possible alternative for driving the winds is radiation pressure on gas. Molecules such as CO and water are important coolants of the gas flow, and their rich infrared and millimeter spectra can be used to probe the physical and chemical structure of the outflow.

The project

In May of 2009, the ESA HERSCHEL Space Observatory was launched successfully, with three scientific instruments on board. The HIFI instrument on board of HERSCHEL will be used to study a large sample of AGB stars within the context of the approved guaranteed time key programme HIFISTARS. The project focuses on an observational analysis of molecular line observations (mainly of CO and water) that will be obtained using HIFI; these data will be combined with data taken in the context of other approved HERSCHEL programmes using the HERSCHEL PACS instrument and with archival data at other wavelengths to obtain a comprehensive view of the physical and chemical structure of AGB winds.

A significant part of the thesis work will involve modeling the HIFI and PACS observations using state of the art radiative transfer models developed at the Institute of Astronomy of Leuven University by Dr. Leen Decin. The project will thus involve close collaboration with the Leuven institute, as well as with the HIFI expertise centre at Groningen.

The position

The position offered is a four year PhD limited term position funded through a NWO "vrije competitie" grant. The research will be conducted at the Astronomical Institute "Anton Pannekoek" of the University of Amsterdam, in close collaboration with the Institute for Astronomy of Leuven University, Belgium. Supervisors will be Prof.Dr. Rens Waters and Dr. Leen Decin. Salaries will be commensurate to the standard scale for PhD students at the University of Amsterdam. The candidate is expected to contribute to the teaching of astronomy courses at the University of Amsterdam.

Interested?

The successful candidate must have a master degree in astrophysics, physics or equivalent. Applications should be sent to Rens Waters (waters@uva.nl) and must include a CV and statement of research interests; please also arrange for two letters of reference (to be sent directly).

fields.title: PhD position on extragalactic spectroscopy with VLT/X-shooter
fields.text:
Astronomical Institute (University of Amsterdam) and Leiden Observatory

The Netherlands Research School for Astronomy (NOVA) plans to start a PhD project at the University of Amsterdam on UV/optical/IR spectroscopy of gamma-ray bursts, to study the structure and evolution of their host galaxies and the state of the intergalactic medium. The research project is a collaboration between the Astronomical Institute Anton Pannekoek at the University of Amsterdam (profs. Kaper and Wijers) and Leiden Observatory (dr. Schaye). The student will predominantly use data from the X-Shooter spectrograph on the ESO Very Large Telescope, obtained via a guaranteed-time programme of the instrument team. The main scientific goal of the programme is to systematically study a significant sample of GRB afterglow and host galaxy spectra, in order to learn about the origin of gamma-ray bursts and the evolution of their host galaxies and environments. The student will work in an international team that includes scientists from The Netherlands, Denmark, UK, Italy, and France, and is expected to regularly participate in collaboration exchanges and meetings in the various participating institutes.

The student will be based in Amsterdam at the new Science Park campus, but also spend significant time at Leiden Observatory. Training will be provided in spectroscopy and in theory of gamma-ray bursts and galaxy evolution, within the context of NOVA, the Dutch Astronomy Research School. Pay and work conditions are according to standard NL university scales. A master's degree in astronomy or physics or equivalent level of preparation are required. For further enquiries you may contact Kaper (L.Kaper@uva.nl), Schaye (schaye@strw.leidenuniv.nl), or Wijers (ralph.wijers@uva.nl). Applications including a CV, diploma and/or transcript must be sent to secr-astro@science.uva.nl with subject 'X-Shooter PhD position'. The applicant must also ensure that 2 letters of reference are sent to the same address. Evaluation of candidates will begin on June 28, 2010, and continue until the position is filled.

fields.text:

Astronomical Institutes of the University of Amsterdam & Utrecht
University and Argelander-Institut für Astronomie, Bonn

The Netherlands Research School for Astronomy (NOVA), in collaboration with the Argelander-Institut für Astronomie in Bonn plans to start two 4 year PhD projects focused on the evolution of the most massive stars in the Tarantula Nebula, to begin Autumn 2010 (start date negotiable).

The successful candidates will participate in the analysis and interpretation of about 1000 early-type stars observed in the VLT/FLAMES Tarantula Survey. This nebula is our closest view of a starburst-like region in the local Universe and is a unique laboratory in which to study stellar evolution. The youth of the Tarantula nebula, plus the presence of several sub-populations from different generations of star formation, ensures that the upper HR diagram is sufficiently well populated with rare, short-lived evolutionary phases to provide strong constraints on theory. One PhD project will focus on a quantitative analysis of a subset of the O-star population, characterizing the stars and studying the effects of rotational mixing and binarity. The other PhD project is aimed at predicting the evolution of binary stars, including the physics of rotation and angular momentum, allowing for a meaningful comparison with VLT/FLAMES and other results.

Applicants should be fluent in English, and have experience in a relevant topic. Experience in programming is a plus. The PhD focussing on the analysis of O stars will initially be based in Amsterdam (in the groups of prof. de Koter and prof. Kaper), but later in Bonn (in the group of prof. Langer). The PhD focussing on stellar evolution will initially be based Bonn, but later in Utrecht (in the group of dr. Pols). Pay and work conditions are according to standard Dutch and German university scales. The positions come with funds for travel and computers.

Interested candidates should have a Master degree in astronomy or physics (or the equivalent) and submit via email (to the address of prof. de Koter) a concise letter of interest and a CV. fields.title: PhD position on the massive star population in low metallicy galaxies
fields.text:
Astronomical Institute, University of Amsterdam

The Netherlands Research School for Astronomy (NOVA), as part of its research program Formation and evolution of stars and planetary systems, plans to start a PhD project at the University of Amsterdam focused on the evolution of the most massive stars in low metallicity Local Group galaxies, to begin Autumn 2010 (start date negotiable).

This study aims at an in-depth census of the massive star populations of several low metallicity dwarf galaxies, such as GR8, LeoA and WLM, targeting both the O- and early-B star population as well as the more evolved population, including Luminous Blue Variable stars and hypergiants. We aim to collect spectra of tens of objects per galaxy. VLT/X-Shooter GTO time has been reserved to execute part of this program. Massive stars in the nearby Magellanic Clouds will also be studied. In this context, data has been secured in the VLT/FLAMES Tarantula Survey. Key questions are: how massive is the most massive star? Do low metallicity stars rotate faster? Can we detect potential progenitors of Gamma Ray Bursts? Are there Luminous Blue Variable stars and if so, what are their properties?

Applicants should be fluent in English, and have experience in a relevant topic. Experience in programming is a plus. The PhD will be based in Amsterdam. Training will be provided in spectroscopy and spectral analysis and in the theory of massive star evolution, within the context of NOVA. Pay and work conditions are according to standard Dutch and German university scales. The position comes with funds for travel and computers.

English is the working language. The institute is only 20 minutes from the heart of Amsterdam, the cultural center of the Netherlands, in a new building on the Amsterdam Science Park.

fields.title: Positions in wide-field radio astronomy, relativistic astrophysics and high-performance computing
fields.text:
Applications are invited for 5 PhD students, 3 postdoctoral fellows, and 1 astronomical software developer to work on the AARTFAAC project. AARTFAAC is a project to extend the LOFAR radio telescope with an all-sky monitor operating in the 30-80MHz band, funded through an ERC Advanced Investigator Grant to prof. Wijers (University of Amsterdam), and to exploit both LOFAR and this extension to study extreme radio transients observationally and theoretically. It will be executed jointly by the University of Amsterdam and ASTRON Netherlands Institute for Radio Astronomy. The project aims to open up new discovery space for very rare transient sources by imaging all the sky, all the time, and to break new ground in the realm of fast, near-real time wide field radio imaging. The research work ranges from developing fast radio data processing techniques to radio survey science and multi-wavelength followup work of selected transients, to theoretical modeling of the extreme astrophysical sources we will observe. Successful applicants will work at the University of Amsterdam or ASTRON, and collaborate widely within the LOFAR community.

The software developer, one postdoc, and two PhD students should start in October 2010 or very soon thereafter; two further postdocs and three PhD students will start in the autumn of 2011, but the timing of all positions is somewhat flexible depending on the availability of suitable candidates. All candidates should be able and willing to collaborate closely in a team. Candidates for the PhD positions should have a Master's degree in astronomy or equivalent, or in computational science with a strong affinity for (astro)physical applications of their work; they should send a CV, statement of motivation, transcript, and 2-3 letters of recommendation to the address below. Candidates for the postdoctoral positions should have a PhD in astronomy (or in a related field with a strong affinity for astronomy); they should send a CV, research and motivation statement, and 3 letters of recommendation the address below. Candidates for the developer position should have a strong track record in scientific software development and a strong affinity with the science described above; they should send their CV, a research and motivation statement, and 3 letters of recommendation to the address below.

Further information about the project, and more detail on individual positions, may be found at www.aartfaac.org. Enquiries about the positions may be made with Prof. Wijers at Ralph.Wijers@uva.nl. All application materials and recommendations should be sent to secr-astro-science@uva.nl. Evaluation of applications will start on October 15 and continue until at least January 1, and then until all positions are filled.

fields.title: Senior and Junior Faculty Positions in Astroparticle Physics
fields.text:
(re-advertisement due to extended deadline and increase in the number of positions)

The Faculty of Science of the University of Amsterdam has launched a major new initiative: GRAPPA - GRavitation and AstroParticle Physics in Amsterdam, and is hiring at least four new faculty for that initiative.

GRAPPA is a collaboration between the Astronomical Institute Anton Pannekoek (API), the Institute for High-Energy Physics (IHEF) and the Institute for Theoretical Physics (ITFA). Each of these institutes already has a programme of research into the fundamental laws of physics using a variety of observational probes of the cosmos and theoretical developments inspitred by these. The intention of the programme is to provide a focused research centre in which these efforts are brought to an even higher level by interdisciplinary collaboration. Some further information on the programme may be found at www.uvaapp.nl.

To jump-start the programme, we are searching at least five new faculty members in senior and junior ranks, tenured or tenure-track. A full professorship is available for an inspiring candidate with leadership qualities and a clear vision on how to make the initiative a world-leading programme in the field by joining the participating institutes' efforts into a coherent programme, as well as proven ability to teach and to attract substantial external research funding.  Junior faculty positions are available to candidates with a proven record of interdisciplinary research in this field, an excellent publication record, and ability to teach inspiringly and attract external research funding. The subfields of research into which the candidates will be hired are not fixed; excellence of the candidates, interdisciplinary interests, and overlap and affinity with the existing work at the UvA will be used to select the candidates, in addition to the above criteria.

Within the context of GRAPPA, we currently focus on the following areas of research:

  • At API, GRAPPA researchers focus on the formation and properties of extreme matter and magnetic fields in strongly curved spacetime, near black holes and neutron stars, and the high-energy messengers emanating from them (X and gamma rays, cosmic rays, neutrinos, gravity waves, radio waves). We are involved in numerous major instrumental initiatives, such as LOFAR, CTA, and many current space instruments, and in theoretical studies of these issues.
  • At IHEF, GRAPPA researchers focus on the study of cosmic neutrinos using the ANTARES and KM3NeT detectors, as well as on accelerator studies of physics beyond the standard model.
  • At ITFA, GRAPPA researchers focus on fundamental aspects of quantum gravity and black-hole physics, and on studies of the physics of the early universe and its measurable impact on present-day observables.

Further information is available at www.uvaapp.nl.  Enquiries about the positions may be made with profs. Stan Bentvelsen (IHEF, stanb@nikhef.nl), Jan de Boer (ITFA, j.deboer@uva.nl), and Ralph Wijers (Ralph.Wijers@uva.nl). Evaluation of the applications will start on January 15, 2011, and continue until the positions are filled.

Applicants should send their CV, a research and teaching statement and three letters of reference, as well as the level of position they are applying for to itf@science.uva.nl.

fields.title: PhD position on the physics and chemistry of metallic Fe and FeS nano clusters
fields.text:
Description of research: metallic Fe nano-particles play an important role in the formation and evolution of solids in space, yet many questions on their stability as well as their spectroscopic and physico-chemical properties have remained unanswered. Metallic Fe plays a key role in the condensation of solid particles in the outflows of evolved stars, and is a main source of opacity in solid material. In interstellar space Fe remains in the solid phase and may take part in the formation of new solids, such as FeS. While FeS is found to be abundan in solar system material, the formation of solid Fe and the possible role of metallic Fe in this process - important because FeS is the dominant source of sulphur in our solar system - is currently not understood. In order to address these issues, gas phase IR spectroscopy of iron and iron sulphide nanoclusters will be conducted using the free electron laser FELIX. The optical properties of these clusters will be investigated by application of UV/VIS spectroscopy. These laboratory data will then be compared to astronomical observations and applied todust grain models in order to investigate the physics and chemistry of Fe in solids in space. The first, experimental part of the research will be conducted using the FELIX free electron laser, currently located at the FOM institute in Nieuwegein and soon to become part of the new F-cube FEL facility at the Radboud University in Nijmegen. The latter part of the thesis work will be located at the University of Amsterdam. Main location will be Amsterdam.

The Amsterdam Astronomy and Chemistry institutes are part of the FNWI faculty and have started a close collaboration in the context of the NWO funded Dutch Astrochemistry network, see the website at: http://www.nwo.nl/nwohome.nsf/pages/NWOP_87XE2N. Two of the ~10 positions in the network are located in Amsterdam. The Astronomical Institute is part of NOVA and its research program focuses on high energy astrophysics and on studies of star and planet formation, and exo-planets. The Molecular Photonics group of the van Ôt Hoff Institute for Molecular Sciences (HIMS) aims to advance the fundamental knowledge of the dynamics of excited states in molecules and nano-sized objects, and to contribute with its expertise to applications of the photosciences.

The  FNWI faculty has moved to a new housing in 2009-2010 and offers a stimulating research environment with excellent infrastructure. Successful applicants should have a master degree in physics, chemistry, astronomy or equivalent. Affinity with laboratory experimental work is desirable. The position will be offered for a period of four years, with an evaluation after 9 or 18 months. Salaries are commensurate to the university salary scale for PhD students. For applications please consult the Astrochemistry website at the link given above, or contact Prof. Rens Waters (waters@uva.nl), Prof. Wybren-Jan Buma (W.J.Buma@uva.nl) or Prof. Jos Oomens (J.Oomens@rijnhuizen.nl) directly. This position will close on April 1st or until a suitable candidate has been found.

fields.title: Faculty Position in Compact Object Astrophysics
fields.text:
A tenured faculty position in observational/interpretative compact object astrophysics is available at the Astronomical Institute Anton Pannekoek (API) of the University of Amsterdam.  Requirements are a PhD in (astro)physics and demonstrable ability for ground-breaking research, to write succesful research/funding proposals, and to teach astrophysics at all levels.

The researcher will join faculty Michiel van der Klis,  Rudy Wijnands and Anna Watts leading and participating in a lively international research group in observations and theory of accreting compact objects and radio pulsars with currently ~10 postdocs and graduate students.  The new position is part of an expanding research programme focusing on rapid time variability observations of black holes and neutron stars, exploration of mathematical techniques to get the physics from the data, and state of the art modeling and theory, all aimed at fundamental questions about strong gravity and dense matter for which we will be hiring six additional postdocs and graduate students in the coming two years.  There are close ties with other research groups at API in relativistic jets, gamma-ray bursts, astroparticle physics, and with groups abroad.

Appointment at assistant/associate professor equivalent levels (UD/UHD) based primarily on previous experience.  Applications with resume, research and teaching statements, publication list highlighting five characteristic ones, and (separately) three letters of reference are requested by closing date but will continue to be considered until the position is filled.

Comprehensive benefits include paid vacation, sick leave, disability insurance, maternity and parental leave, and retirement benefits.  Health care insurance typically amounts to 100 euro/month/person.

Address to: M. van der Klis, Astronomical Institute Anton Pannekoek, University of Amsterdam, PO Box 94249, 1090 GE Amsterdam, Netherlands.

fields.title: Three PhD positions in Black-Hole / Neutron-Star Research
fields.text:

M. van der Klis at the Astronomical Institute Anton Pannekoek (API) of the University of Amsterdam as part of the programme "Signals from Strong-Field Gravity: Getting to the Physics" funded by the Netherlands Organization for Scientific  Research.

Projects in this programme range from more observational to more interpretative and aim at fundamental black-hole and neutron-star (astro)physics such as strong gravity and ultradense matter.  All projects involve state-of-the-art X-ray satellite observations, developing and trying out new approaches and methods for understanding the data, and creating new computer code.

API is a friendly and lively research institute in high energy astrophysics and stellar astronomy comprising some 10 faculty and 40 pre- and postdoctoral researchers, typically ten of who will be your direct colleagues, half of them working on closely related projects.

Requirements are a qualifying academic degree, enthusiasm for the subject and an interest in working with data and mathematical and/or numerical techniques.

Positions are for 4 years and lead to a PhD; there are ample training opportunities but no formal exams except the thesis defence at the end. Part of the job involves undergraduate teaching assistence (no more than 20% of the time).

Applications with resume and motivation letter explaining interests and experience, in a single email or envelope, and (separately) at least one, preferably two letters of reference are requested by closing date but will continue to be considered until positions are filled.

fields.title: Chair `Astronomy, in particular Formation and Evolution of Planets and Stars’
fields.text:
The Astronomical Institute Anton Pannekoek (API) has a dozen faculty and about forty PhD students and postdocs. We are responsible for teaching part of the bachelor curriculum ‘Physics and Astronomy’, run the master programme ‘Astronomy and Astrophysics’, and contribute to the one on ‘Astroparticle Physics’. The Institute is known for research in two broad areas:
(1) Formation and evolution of stars and (exo-)planets & interstellar and circumstellar matter ('low-energy astrophysics');
(2) Relativistic astrophysics and astroparticle physics, specifically the study of the deep potential wells around neutron stars and black holes, jets, gamma-ray bursts and other transients, and pulsars ('high-energy astrophysics').
API is also involved in a significant number of frontier satellite and instrumentation projects, such as Herschel, Chandra, LOFT, LOFAR, and VLT instruments.

In the area of low-energy astrophysics, API is looking for a

Full professor (1.0 fte, 38 hours)

to hold the Chair `Astronomy, in particular Formation and Evolution of Planets and Stars’. We are looking for an ambitious research leader with a high international profile. The successful candidate will conduct a vigorous observational and/or theoretical research programme for which they can attract significant outside funding; they will also ensure that the group plays a strong role in the national and international research context, and to this end make optimal use of the many current and near-future opportunities in the field. The Netherlands continues to have a very attractive funding climate for this type of researcher. The candidate will be an inspiring teacher and help shape the teaching at bachelor, master, and PhD level in their field. A more extensive description of the profile and duties associated with the Chair is available here.

Faculty of Science
The Faculty of Science occupies a leading position internationally in its fields of research and participates in a large number of cooperative programmes with universities, research institutes and businesses. The faculty has a student body of around 3,000 and 1,500 members of staff, spread over eight research institutes and a number of faculty-wide support services. A considerable part of the research is made possible by external funding from Dutch and international organisations and the private sector. The Faculty of Science offers thirteen Bachelor's degree programmes and eighteen Master’s degree programmes in the fields of the natural sciences, mathematics, and computer science. Since September 2010, the whole faculty has been housed in a brand new building at the Science Park in Amsterdam. The instalment of the faculty has made the Science Park one of the largest centres of academic research in the Netherlands.

Information
Information on this position can be obtained from prof. dr. Ralph Wijers, chair of the search committee (Ralph.Wijers@uva.nl).

Candidates should send their CV, publication list, views on their future research and teaching, and names of references to: secr-astro-science@uva.nl  The deadline for receipt of applications is November 1, 2011.

fields.title: Post-doc position "Multi-object spectroscopy on the E-ELT"
fields.text:
The Netherlands Research School for Astronomy (NOVA) is participating in a study for OPTIMOS-EVE, a fiber-fed optical to near-infrared multi-object spectrograph for the European Extremely Large Telescope. The Dutch E-ELT instrumentation program within the framework of the European Strategy Forum on Research Infrastructures (ESFRI) aims at the Dutch participation in the design and construction of at least one E-ELT instrument. The OPTIMOS-EVE consortium is led by Francois Hammer (GEPI Paris, F), Lex Kaper (University of Amsterdam and NOVA, NL), and Gavin Dalton (RAL Oxford, UK); the Project Manager is Ramon Navarro (NOVA-ASTRON, Dwingeloo, NL). The Netherlands is also involved in phase-A studies for multi-object spectrograph concepts on 4-8m-class telescopes (WEAVE on the WHT La Palma, 4MOST on VISTA, and MOONS on the VLT). These projects share several work packages and are relevant for the future development of an E-ELT MOS.

The post-doc position is intended to perform astronomical and technical trade-offs for E-ELT instrumentation in general and OPTIMOS-EVE in particular, in preparation for phase B. The functional description is comparable to that of instrument scientist. The post-doc should be the NL liaison for the ESO E-ELT project office and carry out simulations in support of the E-ELT and OPTIMOS-EVE science case, in collaboration with Eline Tolstoy, Scott Trager and Marc Verheijen (Kapteijn Institute Groningen), and Paul Groot (Radboud University Nijmegen). Important technical aspects relate to the fiber coupling into the spectrograph, i.e. how this affects the overall efficiency, sky-background correction, the application of dichroics, and the use of VPH gratings (in the near-infrared and the trade-off with respect to conventionally ruled gratings).

The FNWI faculty has recently moved to a new building and offers a stimulating research environment with excellent infrastructure. Successful applicants should have a PhD in astronomy, or equivalent, and affinity with instrumentation. The position will be offered for a period of three years, in the research group (Massive stars: on their formation, evolution and fate) of prof. dr. Lex Kaper at the University of Amsterdam. Salaries are commensurate to the university salary scale for postdoctoral fellows. For more information, please contact prof. dr. Lex Kaper (L.Kaper@uva.nl or +31-20 5257474). Applications should include a CV, a list of publications, and three reference letters (to be sent separately); evaluation will start on October 3 and continue until a suitable candidate has been found.

fields.title: Postdoctoral positions in black-hole / neutron-star research
fields.text:
Three postdoc positions are available with prof. M. van der Klis at the Astronomical Institute Anton Pannekoek (API) of the University of Amsterdam in connection with the programme "Signals from Strong-Field Gravity: Getting to the Physics" with funding by the Netherlands Organization for Scientific Research and the Netherlands Royal Academy of Arts and Sciences.   Requirements include a PhD in (astro)physics, demonstrable talent for research and a clear vision of how to contribute to the programme.

Projects should be observational/interpretative in nature, aiming at aspects of black-hole and neutron-star astrophysics such as strong gravity and ultradense matter.  They would typically include state-of-the-art X-ray observations, data analysis-method experimentation and development, and/or creating new computer code.  There is ample opportunity to participate in directing PhD and MSc student projects.

You will join a rapidly growing lively international research group focusing on observations and theory of accreting compact objects, with faculty Michiel van der Klis, Rudy Wijnands, Anna Watts, Phil Uttley and currently ~12 postdocs/graduate students.  There are close ties with other API groups in relativistic jets, gamma-ray bursts, astroparticle physics, and with groups abroad.

Appointments are typically for 3 years with mid-term evaluation and possibilities for obtaining personal grants depending on circumstances.  Applications should comprise resume, research statement, publication list and (separately) two letters of reference.  Positions are to be filled in 2012 / early 2013; applications will be considered continuously starting December 15, 2011 until all positions are filled.

Salary dependent on experience according to Netherlands university pay scales. Comprehensive social benefits. Universal health care insurance typically 100 euro/month/person.

fields.title: Instituuts - coördinator voor API en KdVI
fields.text:
De Faculteit der Natuurwetenschappen, Wiskunde en Informatica (FNWI) neemt op haar onderzoekterreinen internationaal een vooraanstaande plaats in en participeert in een groot aantal samenwerkingsverbanden met zowel universiteiten, onderzoekinstellingen als het bedrijfsleven. De faculteit telt circa 4.000 studenten en 1.500 medewerkers, verspreid over 4 wetenschappelijke disciplines en 8 onderzoekinstituten. Een belangrijk deel van het onderzoek wordt extern gefinancierd door (inter)nationale organisaties en het bedrijfsleven. De FNWI biedt elf bacheloropleidingen en negentien masteropleidingen aan op het gebied van exacte wetenschappen, informatiewetenschappen en levens- en aardwetenschappen.

Sinds september 2010 is de faculteit volledig gehuisvest op Science Park Amsterdam in een gloednieuw gebouw. Het Science Park is met de vestiging van de faculteit een van de grootste centra voor academisch onderzoek in Nederland geworden.

Het Sterrenkundig Instituut Anton Pannekoek verzorgt het onderwijs en onderzoek in de sterrenkunde binnen de faculteit en maakt deel uit van het universitaire zwaartepunt astrodeeltjesfysica. Het instituut maakt deel uit van de Nederlandse top-onderzoekschool NOVA en voert een groot portfolio extern gefinancierd onderzoek uit, in veel nationale en internationale samenwerkingsverbanden.

Het Korteweg-de Vries Instituut voor Wiskunde huisvest het wiskunde onderwijs en onderzoek binnen de Universiteit van Amsterdam. Het onderzoek betreft een groot aantal deelgebieden van de wiskunde, uiteenlopend van zeer zuiver tot direct toepasbaar.

Het Sterrenkundig Instituut Anton Pannekoek (API) en het Korteweg-de-Vries Instituut voor Wiskunde (KdVI) zijn zelfstandige onderzoeksinstituten. Voor beide instituten tezamen, zijn wij op zoek

Instituutscoördinator

voor 38 uur per week
vacaturenummer N11-220

De instituutscoördinator ondersteunt en adviseert de instituutsdirecteuren van API en KdVI ten aanzien van beleids- en besluitvorming op gebied van o.a. de bedrijfsvoering (binnen de context van de faculteit en universiteit) en draagt zorg voor een efficiënte en effectieve organisatie van de bedrijfsvoering van beide instituten. Daartoe voert hij/zij taken uit op algemeen / organisatorisch, financieel en facilitair gebied. Hij/zij is de rechterhand van de directeuren van de instituten en rapporteert aan de directeuren over de dagelijkse gang van zaken. De werktijdverdeling over de beide instituten is: 3 dagen/week API en 2 dagen/week KdVI. De instituutscoördinator werkt nauw samen met de bedrijfsvoerder die het personeelsbeleid van beide instituten uitvoert.

Het betreft een afwisselende, verantwoordelijke functie met vele facetten.

Werkzaamheden

Enkele belangrijke taken zijn:

  • Zorg dragen voor het opstellen van de instituutsbegroting, planning & control cyclus, managementrapportages en het opstellen van de lange-termijn begroting.
  • Bijdragen aan het acquireren, scheppen van voorwaarden voor uitvoering, alsmede het administratief beheren van 2e- en 3e-geldstroomonderzoek en onderwijs aan derden.
  • Toezicht houden op de uitvoering van en verantwoordelijk zijn voor het ARBO-, Milieu- en Veiligheidsbeleid, ICT, de informatievoorziening en faciliteiten binnen het instituut.
  • Advisering bij het formuleren van de wetenschappelijke en algemene strategie en beleid van het instituut, o.a. met betrekking tot de bedrijfsvoering.
  • Coördineren en ondersteunen van wetenschappelijke activiteiten en communicatie van algemene aard (jaarverslag, visitaties, perscontacten ed.).
  • Advisering en geven van ondersteuning met betrekking tot wetenschappelijke projecten en coördinatie van de algemene wetenschappelijk activiteiten van het instituut.
  • In de toekomst wordt de functie uitgebreid met taken op het gebied van personeelsmanagement, zodat doorgroei naar de functie van “instituutsmanager” mogelijk is.

Profiel

Wij zoeken een afgestudeerd wis- natuur- of sterrenkundige, bij voorkeur gepromoveerd, met bewezen affiniteit met financieel- en personeelsmanagement en leidinggeven. Goede communicatieve en sociale vaardigheden én beheersing van de Engelse taal in woord en geschrift is een vereiste. De gezochte kandidaat heeft de ambitie en potentie om op termijn door te groeien naar de functie van “instituutsmanager”.

Inlichtingen

Informatie kan worden verkregen bij de directeuren van beide instituten:
prof.dr. R.A.M.J. Wijers (R.A.M.J.Wijers@uva.nl) en
prof.dr. J.J.O.O. Wiegerinck (J.J.O.O.Wiegerinck@uva.nl)

Het e-mail-adres voor uw sollicitatie vindt u onderaan de advertentietekst.

Aanstelling

Wij bieden een positie in een stimulerende academische omgeving en een dynamische, internationale atmosfeer. Aanstelling geschiedt in tijdelijke dienst voor twee jaar ter beoordeling van de geschiktheid voor de functie. Na gebleken geschiktheid wordt u aangesteld in vaste dienst. Het salaris is
afhankelijk van ervaring en bedraagt maximaal 4.374,- euro bruto per maand (schaal 11) op basis van de volledige werktijd (38 uur). Het loopbaanperspectief is doorgroei naar de functie van “instituutsmanager”, die is gewaardeerd in schaal 12/13 (maximaal 4.970,- / 5.390,- euro bruto per maand). De CAO Nederlandse Universiteiten is van toepassing met o.a. een
vakantie-uitkering van 8 % en een eindejaarsuitkering van 8,3 %.

Sollicitatie

Uw schriftelijke sollicitatie, onder vermelding van het vacaturenummer, vergezeld van een curriculum vitae en ‘strikt vertrouwelijk’ in de linkerbovenhoek van de envelop, kunt u vóór 1 februari 2012 richten aan de Dienst Personeelszaken, Universiteit van Amsterdam, Faculteit der Natuurwetenschappen, Wiskunde en Informatica, Postbus 94216, 1090 GE Amsterdam.

Solliciteren per e-mail (application-science@uva.nl) onder vermelding van het vacaturenummer als onderwerp en relevante documenten als bijlage, is ook mogelijk.

De eerste ronde sollicitatiegesprekken zal worden gehouden op 16 februari 2012. Geselecteerde kandidaten ontvangen hierover op 10 februari 2012 bericht. Een assessment kan deel uitmaken van de selectieprocedure.

fields.title: PhD student position in X-ray source populations in old star clusters
fields.text:
A PhD position is available with Dr Maureen van den Berg and Dr Rudy Wijnands in the High Energy Astrophysics group of the Astronomical Institute "Anton Pannekoek" at the University of Amsterdam. The research is observationally oriented and will focus on unraveling the nature of the low-luminosity X-ray source populations in globular and old open star clusters. The successful applicant will work with optical (ground-based, HST) and X-ray (mainly Chandra) data. By studying the properties of a wide variety of systems (active binaries, accreting compact objects, milli-second pulsars) we gain a better picture of the dynamical processes that are active in different environments as well as the physical processes at work in those binary systems.

The Astronomical Institute at UvA is a vibrant group with more than 40 PhD students and postdocs, and about a dozen scientific staff members. The institute is part of the Netherlands Research School for Astronomy (NOVA). Through the yearly NOVA school for PhD students and meetings of the Dutch Astronomical Society you will get to know PhD students at the other national institutes. As is common in the Dutch PhD program, part of your time (20% at most) is spent on duties as teaching assistant. 

We seek a motivated candidate holding a Master degree (or equivalent) in Astronomy or a related field. The appointment is for 4 years, with a required starting date before December 31, 2012. Your application should be sent by email to Dr van den Berg (M.C.vandenBerg@uva.nl), and must include a cover letter (with preferred starting date), resume, and brief (1 page) statement of research interests and experience. Please arrange to have at least one letter of reference (preferably by your Master thesis supervisor) emailed separately. Review of applications starts on August 15, and continues until the position is filled. Interviews are expected to be scheduled in the second half of September. Informal inquiries regarding this position are welcome, and can be sent to Dr van den Berg.

The salary is in accordance with the university regulations for academic personnel (Collective Labour Agreement, Dutch Universities) and will range from 2,042 euro (first year) up to a maximum of 2,612 euro (last year) gross per month (scale P). The annual salary will be supplemented with an 8% holiday allowance and an 8.3% end-of-year bonus. Medical insurance is about 100 euro per month.

fields.title: PhD position: The particle acceleration properties of clusters of galaxies
fields.text:
Team:  Jacco Vink (supervisor), Shin’ichiro Ando, Michael Wise, Ralph Wijers

Clusters of galaxies are the largest bound structures in the Universe, and consist of dark matter, hot (107-108K) tenuous plasma and, of course, thousands of galaxies. Clusters still accrete material from the intergalactic medium, leading to shocks in the intracluster medium, but also AGN lead to shocks and form a source of relativistic electrons and protons. For this project we want to investigate the properties of cluster shocks, which although high speed (> 1000 km/s) are low Mach number shocks (M<3). This investigation will be a combination of theoretical study and observations based on Fermi-satellite data.

This PhD position is part of the GRAPPA graduate program.

The deadline for application is December 20, and follows the general rules laid out for the graduate program. Candidates will be invited in January for an interview/presentation meeting in February.

fields.title: NOVA PhD positions at the Astronomical Institute Anton Pannekoek in Amsterdam
fields.text:
The Astronomical Institute Anton Pannekoek (API) at the University of Amsterdam invites applications for up to 10 PhD positions funded by the Netherlands Research School for Astronomy (NOVA).   The positions are open to candidates from all countries. 

PhD students in Amsterdam execute a vigorous research program lasting four years, under the supervision of one or more faculty members.  Positions will be available in all fields of research where the Institute is active, including Neutron Stars and Black Holes, Cosmic Explosions, Protoplanetary Disks and Planet Formation, Massive Stars and their Formation. These positions will also run alongside the PhD program of the GRAPPA (GRavitation and AstroParticle Physics in Amsterdam) Institute, in which the API plays a key role (see http://grappa.science.uva.nl/graduateprogram/).

More information on our research can be found at http://www.astro.uva.nl/research/.  

University of Amsterdam PhD students are appointed as civil servants and earn competitive salaries.  PhD positions are funded for four years.  Applicants should provide a curriculum vitae, a list of all university courses taken and grades obtained, and a statement of research interests and experience.  

Specific NOVA PhD project descriptions can be found here:  http://www.astro.uva.nl/jobs/nova-phd-project-descriptions/.  All shortlisted applicants will be asked to specify project preferences in mid-January, but applicants are also welcome to suggest projects from this list that interest them in in their application e-mail/cover-letter (this is not mandatory however).  New projects will be added to the list, so check back for further project descriptions.

All materials should be sent to secr-astro-science@uva.nl with the e-mail subject line "PhD Application: <your name>"

Applicants should also arrange for at least two letters of reference to be sent directly to the same email address (with the e-mail subject line: "PhD Recommendation for <your name>").

The successful candidates must have a MSc degree (or equivalent) by the starting date. The starting dates are negotiable.

Applications need to be submitted before December 20, 2012. By mid January we will invite promising candidates for a presentation and interviews to be held on February 13 and 14.

fields.text:
If the dark matter of the universe is a new particle that can be produced in pairs in proton-proton collisions at CERN’s Large Hadron Collider (LHC), it may be found in analyses involving missing transverse momentum. The student will work on a search for new physics in events with missing transverse momentum at the ATLAS experiment, focussing on the dark matter context. She or he is given the opportunity to spend time at CERN in Switzerland to work on this analysis and participate in experiment operations and preparations for higher-energy LHC running in 2015.

This PhD position is part of the GRAPPA graduate program.

fields.title: NOVA PhD project descriptions
fields.text:
These are the descriptions of projects which will be available under the NOVA PhD programme.  Please keep checking back for more projects as the list gets updated.  

 

1.  Faint X-ray source populations in different environments: from the Galactic plane to the cores of dense star clusters

Supervisor:  Maureen van den Berg (UvA)

Co-Supervisor:  Rudy Wijnands (UvA)

The central regions of star clusters can be so dense (with more than thousand times the stellar density of our local environment) that it affects the way stars evolve. Dynamical encounters between cluster stars can create exotic binaries that are very rare in the field, but they can also lead to binary destruction, resulting in a dearth of certain classes of systems that are typically relatively common. Such interacting binaries are bright sources of X-ray emission. Thanks to the sensitivity and sharp view of the Chandra X-ray Observatory we can now start studying in detail the balance between forming and breaking up binaries by comparing the properties of cluster and field binary populations. This project will take the vantage point of the latter, and focuses on those binary classes that so far have received little attention due to their low X-ray luminosities (~1e32 erg/s or less), including magnetically-active binaries. The work is (initially) mainly observationally oriented, and the successful applicant will have the opportunity to apply for, gather, and analyze both ground-based and satellite data (e.g. from Chandra, and the Hubble Space Telescope).

 

2.  Models of extrasolar planets and disks for studies in polarized light

Supervisor: Carsten Dominik (UvA)

Co-supervisors: Christoph Keller (Leiden), Matthew Kenworthy (Leiden)

An internal consortium is currently building a new instrument for the Very Large Telescope in Chile:  The SPHERE instrument is an extreme adaptive optics instrument designed for high contrast imaging, for discovery and study of extrasolar planets and circumstellar disks.  Together with a group at the ETH in Zürich, we are building the optical polarimeter ZIMPOL.  The PhD student will further develop polarized radiative transfer codes to explain the upcoming ZIMPOL measurements of proto-planetary disks and mature/cold gas giant exoplanets, making use of the world-leading expertise in the Netherlands. By 2014, SPHERE science data will be collected, and a first-order characterization of gas giants will be possible by measuring their intensity and linear polarization at a few wavelengths. The PhD student will focus on modeling signals by adapting existing models of gas planet atmospheres and (polarized) radiative transfer and polarized spectrum codes, to explain the SPHERE observations as well as spectropolarimetric observations of solar-system gas planets. These codes together will provide a data retrieval package that will allow us to quantitatively understand the atmospheres of mature/cold gas exoplanets.  In addition, the student will also work on radiative transfer models of circumstellar disks, another key aspect of research with SPHERE/ZIMPOL.

 

3.  LOTAAS: The LOFAR Tied-Array All-Sky Survey for Pulsars and Fast Transients

Supervisor: Jason Hessels (ASTRON/UvA)

Co-Supervisors: J. van Leeuwen (ASTRON/UvA), R. Wijers (UvA), H. Falcke (Nijmegen) & M. van der Klis (UvA)

The successful PhD candidate will work on `LOTAAS', an all-northern-sky survey for pulsars and fast transients using the LOFAR high-band antennas.  LOTAAS will take advantage of LOFAR's unparalleled field-of-view and multi-beaming capabilities to perform the deepest all-sky survey ever undertaken for pulsars and any other radio pulses with sub-second durations.  The survey is in many ways different from previous pulsar surveys (e.g., much longer dwell times and lower frequency) and the potential for the serendipitous discovery of new source classes and physical phenomena is high, especially because of the unprecedented `total on-sky' time the survey will achieve.  We have demonstrated the technical feasibility and scientific potential of LOTAAS through two pilot surveys performed during LOFAR's commissioning period and have recently started acquiring data for this all-sky survey.  

 

4.  The formation and early evolution of the most massive stars

Supervisor: Lex Kaper (UvA)

The recent development of sensitive spectroscopic techniques at near-infrared wavelengths allows for the first time direct detections and quantitative analysis of characteristics of massive proto-stars. These so-called massive Young Stellar Objects (YSOs) must represent a later phase of formation than the luminous extended disk sources that can be detected at (sub-) millimeter wavelengths, though it is unclear at the moment how these two phases are related. In this project we will study the physical link between these two, likely sequential, phases of massive star formation by combining ALMA and near-IR imaging and spectroscopy of star-forming regions in the Milky Way and Local Group galaxies, in particular the Magellanic Clouds. Such a multi-wavelength approach will allow us to study massive star formation in an environmental context, including aspects of metallicity and cluster mass/density. By establishing the physical properties of the newly formed stars – such as photospheric parameters, binary properties, rotational characteristics, ionizing fluxes, and radiation-driven winds – we will assess the importance of feedback from this new population on the star formation process in general. State-of-the art spectroscopic analysis methods essential for these studies are currently being developed in the group of De Koter at the UvA.

 

5.  ALERT – the Apertif Legacy Exploration of the Radio Transient Sky

Supervisor: Joeri van Leeuwen (UvA/ASTRON)

Co-supervisors: Jason Hessels (ASTRON/UvA), Michiel van der Klis (UvA), Ralph Wijers (UvA) & Heino Falcke (Nijmegen)

In our largely constant radio Universe, a highly dynamic component was recently discovered: flashes of bright radio emission that last only milliseconds but appear all over the sky. Some of these short-lived radio bursts can be traced to neutron stars, but the extremely limited activity has so far prevented determination of the origin and formation of this neutron-star population.  Other bursts apparently originate far outside our Galaxy, and defy any explanation.  Due to great observational challenges the nature of these extragalactic bursts remains a mystery.  In ``ALERT'', we will carry out by far the deepest all-sky search for radio bursts ever undertaken. Exploiting the novel wide-field Apertif receivers on Westerbork, we will increase by a factor of 10 our exploration volume for fast transients throughout the Universe, and use these data to both map the population intermittently bursting neutron stars, and characterize and localize extragalactic bursts; to finally, and for the first time, understand the origin of both.

 

6.  How does Sgr A* relate to other black holes?  

Supervisor:  Sera Markoff (UvA)

Co-supervisors:  Heino Falcke & Elmar Körding (Nijmegen); Elena Rossi & Simon Portegies Zwart (Leiden) 

The Galactic center is our closest galactic nucleus, harboring the weakest known accreting supermassive black hole, Sgr A*.    Sgr A* has been the driver for many theoretical studies of radiatively inefficient accretion and jet launching, and we are now at a stage where years of semi-analytical models by the PI and others are converging with predictions from sophisticated MHD simulations (see eg. Dibi et al. 2012).   However many questions still exist, particularly about the existence of a fully collimated jet outflow, and the spin of the black hole.   Sgr A* also exhibits roughly daily X-ray flares, often simultaneous with the IR, hinting at stochastic plasma processes including magnetic reconnection and particle acceleration events.   Sgr A* is thus the ideal testbed for accretion inflow/outflow theory, plasma astrophysics, particle acceleration and general relativity, and an important source for quantifying AGN activity in “normal” galaxies.   NOVA-4 falls at an extremely opportune time, between an unprecedented multiwavelength campaign in 2012 centered around a 3Msec Chandra X-ray Visionary Project, and an infalling gas cloud predicted to encounter Sgr A* in mid 2013.   In this project we will focus on semi-analytical models (guided by MHD simulations performed within the cluster, via CoI Körding), to develop new models that account for time-dependent particle evolution as well as MHD-consistent jet models that link inflow to outflow for the first time.   We will build on groundwork from recent papers deriving new MHD flow solutions (Polko, Meier & Markoff 2010, 2012a,b) that allow an unambiguous connection between the jet dynamics and particle acceleration.  The Fermi Bubbles and X-ray light echos in the Galactic center further hint at Sgr A* having been significantly more active in the past, and based on its renewed activity, we will also make predictions for the emission of Sgr A* during the past, and test it against the current limits.  The project will be carried out by a PhD student based at UvA, with close ties to RU and UL within the GC cluster.   The student will have proprietary access to a large array of new data from the XVP and associated multiwavelength campaigns.   Though the project is focused primarily on Sgr A*, much of the work will also apply to other nearby AGN such as M81, M87, M31, M33 etc, and related studies can be expected.   We will use the new campaign data to place Sgr A* firmly into context with other low luminosity AGN.  

 

7.  Revealing the clockwork: the physical origin of low-frequency quasi-periodic oscillations in black holes and neutron stars

Supervisor: Phil Uttley (UvA)

Co-Supervisors: Michiel van der Klis (UvA), Mariano Mendez (Kapteyn Institute, Groningen)

The quasi-periodic oscillations (QPOs) in the X-ray light curves of black holes and neutron stars are clocks that probe the conditions in extreme gravity close to the compact object. The origin of the QPOs is not yet settled, but could relate to instabilities in the mass-accretion flow, or alternatively, to the precession of the flow in the strongly-curved space-time close to the compact object.  If this puzzle can be solved, we will unveil a wealth of new information about the most extreme objects in the universe.  Now, using newly-developed spectral-timing techniques, X-ray observations of black holes and neutron stars allow us to ‘map’ the structure and motion of matter as it accretes on to the compact object, by measuring time-lags between variations in the emission from the different components of the accretion flow, as they respond to fluctuations in the mass accretion rate and/or changes in the geometry of the system.   Neutron stars also generate emission as matter hits the solid surface, so that we should see clear differences in the time-lag behaviour between neutron stars and black holes.  This project will combine measurements of the time-lags from X-ray observations of neutron star and black hole X-ray binaries with models for the QPO, to try to finally reveal the origin of these enigmatic signals.

 

8.  Supernova remnants and pulsar wind nebulae observations with LOFAR

Supervisor: Jacco Vink (UvA)

Co-Supervisors: Marijke Haverkorn (Nijmegen), Jason Hessels (ASTRON/UvA), Joeri van Leeuwen (ASTRON/UvA)

The estimated number of SNRs in the Galaxy is 1500-3000, whereas the detected number of SNRs is less than 300. Finally, LOFAR will reveal a whole new aspect of SNRs and related sources such as pulsar wind nebulae, because the low frequency radio domain has only poorly been explored. This low frequency domain is connected to the acceleration of low energy cosmic rays, which are an pressure component and source of ionization in the Galaxy.

 

9.  Radio bursts from magnetars

Supervisor: Anna Watts (UvA)

Co-Supervisors: Jason Hessels (ASTRON/UvA), Joeri van Leeuwen (ASTRON/UVA), Alexander van der Horst (UvA)

Highly magnetic neutron stars, known as magnetars, emit regular bursts of gamma-ray emission that are thought to be associated with magnetic reconnection and particle acceleration.  The process is similar to that involved in solar flares, although heavily modified by processes unique to such strong magnetic fields.  This has led to speculation that magnetar bursts, like solar flares, might be accompanied by radio bursts, which would provide new insight into the trigger process and burst energetics.  This project will study prospects for radio emission from magnetar bursts, to determine whether this offers a means of distinguishing competing physical models for burst trigger and emission processes.  This theoretical study will support and provide the means to interpret a simultaneous multi-wavelength magnetar burst monitoring campaign using the Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor and the LOFAR and Westerbork radio telescopes.

 

10.  Black-hole ejecta physics: Spectro-temporal modeling of tidal disruption events

Supervisor: Ralph Wijers (UvA)

Co-supervisors: Sera Markoff (UvA), Elmar Koerding (Nijmegen), Heino Falcke (Nijmegen)

Transient jets address basic physics problems both in their generation (engines), their outward transport (jets) and their eventual dissipation (AGN lobes, GRB blast waves). We will combine AGN and GRB modeling expertise to make the full connection between all three, and use tidal disruption events to test the resulting models, since these are one of the few where one can observe all phenomena from engine to jet dissipation.

The student will learn the principles of disk/jet physics and jet/GRB dissipation. She will then develop a framework in which a joint model of the generation of a jet and its final dissipation is constructed, with a well-defined set of free parameters (e.g., temporal profile of accreted matter, black-hole mass, ambient density, jet efficiency, etc.) and model a complete event from the tidal disruption to the final dissipation of energy. Some phases can already be connected ab initio, in some other phases we will make use of empirically derived correlations, such as the BH accretion fundamental plane, if need be. The outcome will be models of the SED of the event as a function of time, depending on a set of parameters, and fits of those modes to a few good data sets. Whether such fits are possible, and yield plausible parameters, will test our understanding of the physics.

 

11.  AGN Feedback and SMBH Growth with LOFAR

Supervisor: Michael Wise (ASTRON/UvA)

Co-Supervisors: George Heald (ASTRON/Groningen), Jacco Vink (UvA), Phil Uttley (UvA)

We propose to use exciting new data from LOFAR’s first all-sky survey to study such open questions as how black holes grow over cosmic time, how feedback from black holes moderates the growth of galaxies, and how the combined effects of black hole feedback and mergers determine the growth of the large-scale structure that we observe. As the largest gravitationally bound objects, clusters retain an archeological record of the integrated effects of these physical processes over a significant fraction of the age of the Universe. The hot atmospheres of clusters serve as a repository for the exhaust generated by the growth of supermassive black holes (SMHBs) in the forms of excess entropy, relativistic particles, and magnetic fields. Radio sources trace the enormous amount of mechanical energy deposited into the ICM by SMBHs and may be the principal agent dispersing chemical elements created by stellar evolution throughout the intercluster and intergalactic medium. SMBHs are now believed to play a central role in galaxy formation through a feedback process that regulates both star formation in the host galaxy and the rate of accretion onto the black hole. Low frequency radio observations represent a unique and powerful new tool to probe this archeological record in galaxy clusters. We will use the results of new and ongoing all-sky surveys with LOFAR to study these effects in the largest sample of clusters ever obtained at low radio frequencies. The process of amassing this new data is well underway as LOFAR has already begun its first all-sky, pathfinder survey (MSSS) earlier this year and a large fraction of the survey data is already available to be explored. Now is the ideal time for such a study as LOFAR will provide the largest and most sensitive catalog of radio observations on clusters ever obtained in this frequency range and down to frequencies that have never been probed before. The project will be done in collaboration with staff members at ASTRON, the University of Amsterdam, and Leiden University as well as researchers in France, Germany, and the United States.

fields.title: PhD position: The formation and early evolution of the most massive stars
fields.text:
The Netherlands Research School for Astronomy (NOVA), as part of its research program Formation and evolution of stars and planetary systems, plans to start a PhD project at the University of Amsterdam focused on the formation and early evolution of the most massive stars.

The mechanism by which the massive stars (M > 8 Msun) form is poorly understood. Even though they are the most luminous objects in the Galaxy, their formation process and early evolution are obscured from view due to the tens to hundreds of magnitudes of (visual) extinction. The recent development of sensitive spectroscopic techniques at near-infrared wavelengths allows for the first time direct detections and quantitative analysis of the characteristics of massive proto-stars. These objects are surrounded by a disk and, in case the photospheric spectrum can be detected, turn out to be “bloated” stars, i.e. are apparently still contracting towards the main sequence. These so-called massive Young Stellar Objects (YSOs) must represent a later phase of formation than the luminous extended disk sources that can be detected at (sub-)millimeter wavelengths, though it is unclear at the moment how these two phases are precisely related. In this project we will study the physical link between these two, likely subsequent phases of massive star formation by combining ALMA and near-IR imaging and spectroscopy of star-forming regions in the Milky Way and Local Group galaxies, in particular the Magellanic Clouds.

Such a multi-wavelength approach will allow us to study massive star formation in an environmental context, including aspects of metallicity and cluster mass/density. By establishing the physical properties of the newly formed stars – such as photospheric parameters, binary properties, rotational characteristics, ionizing fluxes, and radiation-driven winds – we will assess the importance of feedback from this new population on the star formation process in general.  State-of-the art spectroscopic analysis methods essential for these studies are currently being developed in the group of prof. De Koter at the UvA.

Our strategy will be to extend the covered wavelength range of the many candidate young massive stars, thereby directly probing the stellar photosphere and wind. Optical/nIR spectra have been (and will be) obtained with X-shooter on the ESO Very Large Telescope in Chile. One of the goals of the project is to relate the found results to observations obtained at longer wavelengths (e.g. ALMA). Reduction, analysis, and interpretation of the obtained data, including the collection of new data, will form a major part of the project that should lead to a PhD at the University of Amsterdam. The position is offered for a period of 4 years and should be taken up in the Fall of 2013. The salary will be on the standard Dutch university scale.

Interested candidates should have a Master degree in astronomy or physics (or the equivalent). Applications should contain a curriculum vitae, a statement of research experience and motivation, and the names of two references, to be sent to:

Prof.dr. L. Kaper, Sterrenkundig Instituut Anton Pannekoek, Universiteit van Amsterdam, Postbus 94249, 1090 GE Amsterdam.

Review of the applications will start on July 1, 2013, and continue until the position is filled.

fields.title: Resolving the star formation history in the Gould belt with Gaia
fields.text:
Supervisor: Lex Kaper

The Gould belt is a ring-like structure of stars and gas of about 1 kpc across, tilted toward the Galactic plane by about 20 degrees, and containing essentially all nearby OB associations including Orion and the Sco-Cen region.  Most of the ISM in the Solar vicinity is expanding with a mean velocity of 2 - 5 km/s from a point located near the 50 Myr old Cas-Tau group, a "fossil" OB association (Blaauw 1991).  This expanding ring of gas, with the Sun well inside, was first identified by Lindblad (1967), and appears to be a 30 - 60 Myr old super shell driven into the local ISM by the Cas-Tau group and the associated alpha Per cluster.  The Gould belt of stars, nearby OB associations, and star forming dark clouds may thus represent secondary star formation in clouds that condensed from the ancient Lindblad's ring super shell.

Using Gaia we will disentangle the detailed spatial and kinematical distribution of the young stellar population in the Gould belt, and thus the recent star formation history of this important part of the Milky Way.  Note that even in a well-studied region as Orion we essentially do not know the distribution of the stellar population along the line of sight.  This complicates cluster membership and age determinations.  Gaia will revolutionize our view on the Gould belt, will provide important information on the triggering and progression of (massive) star formation in the nearby Galaxy, and give insight into the uniqueness of this environment. 

Gaia will be launched in 2013 and is expected to provide the first data in 2015; with the first data release (end 2015) the Hundred Thousand Proper Motions catalogue will be published (cf. De Bruijne & Eilers 2012), an update of the Hipparcos catalogue with 20x smaller errors on proper motions. This should already lead to a major improvement of our knowledge of the nearby OB associations (De Zeeuw et al. 1999), the nature of the Gould belt, and the origin of OB runaway stars.

fields.title: Catch the magnet!
fields.text:
Supervisor: Nanda Rea

The properties of matter under extreme conditions are key areas of research in physics, biology, bioengineering, chemistry, geology and many other branches of science. However, despite decades of research, our ignorance on many physical processes related with strong gravity and extreme magnetic fields is vast: note that the strongest steady magnetic field achieved in terrestrial labs is some hundreds of Tesla, only thousands of times stronger than a common refrigerator magnet. In order to test our theoretical predictions for new physical processes and the state of matter under the most extreme conditions, we have only one possibility: turn to high-energy astronomical observations, and in particular studying the strongest magnets in the Universe: neutron stars.

The applicant is expected to work on neutron stars from an observational perspective, gaining experience in X-ray and radio observational techniques, analyzing X-ray observations of strongly magnetized neutron stars and performing radio timing analysis of a large number of radio pulsars aiming at measuring their braking indexes. This observational study might lead to the discovery of new transient magnetars, and coupled with the group theoretical efforts, can give answers to many open questions about fundamental physics at the extreme conditions met in neutron stars.

Past experience in data analysis is appreciated, as it is a background on neutron star physics, but neither of them is strictly required. We are seeking for a candidate with an excellent university record, an independent research approach, a strong motivation, and keen for pleasant teamwork. The applicant is expected to travel between Barcelona and Amsterdam during part of his/her appointment.

fields.title: Impact of Massive Binary stars throughout Cosmic Times
fields.text:
Supervisor: Selma de Mink

Co-supervisor: Alex de Koter

Massive stars are rare and short lived.  Yet they have played a major role in shaping the Universe from the pristine conditions left after the Big Bang into the Universe in which we live today.  With their large luminosities, strong stellar winds and spectacular explosions they act as cosmic engines; they heat and enrich their surroundings, where the next generation of stars and their planets are forming. 

Massive stars do not live their lives alone: they are normally found to have companions.  The majority will exchange mass with the nearest neighbor before ending their life. This has an enormous impact on the further evolution of both stars and leads to many exotic phenomena such as Blue stragglers, X-ray binaries and gamma ray bursts.  

In this project you will learn to work with state of the art computer models to simulate the physics of stellar evolution and binary interaction.  You will help to further develop these codes to study how these effects influence entire stellar populations of massive stars.   

The work is theoretical and computational, but directly driven by observations. In your role as a theorist you will be encouraged to become an active member of one or more international collaborations organized around large observing campaigns with the Hubble Space Telescope and Very Large Telescope in Chile.

fields.title: Formation, structure and evolution of rocky exoplanets - an interdisciplinary study combining theory and laboratory experiments
fields.text:
Supervisors: Carsten Dominik and Wim van Westrenen

Searches for extrasolar planets now under way are finding large numbers of rocky exoplanets, with sizes from smaller than Mercury to so-called super-earths with up to 2.5 times the radius of the earth. A large fraction of these planets are located at distances very close to the star, including rocky planets that might be in the process of evaporation.  These planets are so close to the host star that it has to be expected that material-selective chemistry and evaporation processes may have had a significant role in determining their bulk chemical composition.  Coupling such extreme compositions to astronomical observables (ranging from mass-radius measurements to atmosphere/surface spectroscopic data) requires knowledge of the interior structure of these exoplanets, but to date such models are either very simplified or absent.   

We are looking for a candidate with interest in an interdisciplinary PhD project that comprises both theoretical modeling work and an experimental lab component.  The student will be stationed at the University of Amsterdam, but spend at least 1 day a week in the high-pressure lab at VU University Amsterdam, providing a unique opportunity for an interdisciplinary research project.

We aim to study the full range of possible planetary compositions as they result from studies of hot planet formation in disks near the sublimation limit close to the star.  We will study protoplanetary disks and determine the chemical composition of the building blocks for planets in the innermost regions.  We will derive a range of possible compositions in terms of major elements (C, O, H, S, Si, Fe, Mg, Ca, Al) which will include extreme compositions.  We will then construct models of planetary interiors according to these compositions using a combination of thermodynamic modeling and high-pressure experimentation.   These models will provide more realistic mass-radius relations and constraints on surface and atmosphere composition for comparison with observations.

This project is part of the Planetary and Exoplanetary Research Programme funded by NWO. The student will be part of a close collaboration between Dutch Universities on the subject of Exoplanetary Research.

fields.title: Mixing processes driven by condensation and dust-gas separation in protoplanetary disks
fields.text:
Supervisor: Carsten Dominik

Protoplanetary disks are locations where planets form.  Due to the explosion of Exoplanet discoveries in recent years, it is becoming clear that an enormous variety of exoplanetary systems exist, including variations in orbital setup and structure, mass distribution and chemical composition.  At the same time, submm interferometers are revolutionizing the study of protoplanetary disks, providing spatial maps of the distribution of molecules and dust in disks, including measurements of snowlines for different materials.  Dust particles moving around in disks will cross such snowlines and cause complex transport processes that will be key to understanding the elemental and molecular abundances in disks.

We are looking for a PhD candidate who will focus on the study of condensation and evaporation-driven transport processes.  Models of such processes will be constructed using the protoplanetary disk code MCMax developed in Amsterdam by M. Min.  These models will then be applied to the wealth of observational data expected from ALMA in the coming years.

Our group studying the structure and physics of protoplanetary disks is one of the leading groups in the world in this area.  Close collaborations exist with other key groups in Heidelberg, Grenoble, Groningen and Leiden.  The Netherlands is hosting one of the regional ALMA centers, providing first class support for proposing for and analyzing ALMA data.

The Anton Pannekoek Institute is on the same campus as the National supercomputing center SARA, hosting the Cartesius supercomputer and the LISA Linux cluster, providing access to world-class computing facilities.

fields.title: ALERT – the Apertif Legacy Exploration of the Radio Transient Sky
fields.text:
Supervisor: Joeri van Leeuwen

In our largely constant radio Universe, a highly dynamic component was recently discovered: flashes of bright radio emission that last only milliseconds but appear all over the sky. Some of these short-lived radio bursts can be traced to neutron stars, but the extremely limited activity has so far prevented determination of the origin and formation of this neutron-star population.  Other bursts apparently originate far outside our Galaxy, and defy any explanation.  Due to great observational challenges the nature of these extragalactic bursts remains a mystery.  In "ALERT", we will carry out by far the deepest all-sky search for radio bursts ever undertaken. Exploiting the novel wide-field Apertif receivers on Westerbork, we will increase by a factor of 10 our exploration volume for fast transients throughout the Universe, and use these data to both map the population intermittently bursting neutron stars, and characterize and localize extragalactic bursts; to finally, and for the first time, understand the origin of both.

fields.title: Exploring the transient radio sky with LOFAR
fields.text:
Supervisor: Jason Hessels

This PhD project will make the deepest ever exploration for "fast radio transients".  Fast radio transients, like pulsars, are only visible for a few milliseconds but provide unique information about the highest-energy-density environments in the Universe.  The student will perform ground-breaking observations with the LOFAR telescope, which provides unprecedented sensitivity and wide field-of-view at the lowest observable radio frequencies from Earth.  The student will be responsible for the organization, acquisition, analysis, and quality control of the data.  They will lead the follow-up science related to newly discovered sources.

The ultimate goal of this observational project is to discover new types of astrophysical phenomena and to use these to probe fundamental physics.  This includes an all-sky pulsar survey, which will provide a full census of the nearby population.  A hot target are the recently identified "Fast Radio Bursts", which are believed to be a new, extragalactic source class that can be used to probe the matter between galaxies.  If these bursts are detectable at low radio frequencies, then LOFAR can detect such a burst every 10 hours.

fields.title: Building a monumental pulsar monitoring program with LOFAR
fields.text:
Supervisor: Jason Hessels

This PhD project will create and exploit a unique new system that is capable of regularly observing hundreds of radio pulsars.  Radio pulsars are famous for their clock-like precision, which not only allows us to measure their characteristics but also turns pulsars into unique astrophysical laboratories for studying fundamental physics. The student will mold the unique observing capabilities of the LOFAR telescope into a system that can observe dozens of pulsars at once - spread over the sky - and which can monitor hundreds of sources on a regular basis.  The student will be responsible for the organization, acquisition, analysis, and quality control of the data.  They will lead the follow-up science related to newly discovered phenomena.

The ultimate goal of this project is to create a database of pulsar times-of-arrival and other related data products that can be mined to study pulsar intermittency, variations in the interstellar medium, and to use these pulsars as precision astrophysical laboratories.  All of these will be studied at the lowest accessible radio frequencies, which is a largely unexplored spectral domain with the potential for big surprises and new insights.
