fields.title: Post-doctoral position (2+1 years) on neutron stars
fields.text:
Applications are invited for one Post-Doctoral research position at the "Anton Pannekoek" Astronomical Institute of the University of Amsterdam within an NWO Vidi Grant (PI: Nanda Rea).

Despite being governed by a single equation of state, the diversity in which these objects appear to us is still a big mistery. The neutron star class is divided in several sub-classes, apparently having different emission properties. We have recently shown via a 2D magneto-thermal evolutionary code, how a single evolutionary scenario driven by the magnetic field strength and geometry at birth, and age, can qualitatively explain the neutron star diversity.

The applicant is expected to build a 3D magneto-thermal evolution code from the present 2D version developed at the University of Alicante by the group of Prof. Jose' Pons. The aim is to study and incorporate the dynamics of the magnetic field in the neutron star core (taking into account the poorly understood effects of superconductivity, buoyancy, interaction with neutron vortices...). These improvements should lead to much more realistic simulations of the complex evolution of magnetic field in a neutron star, and will allow to progress enormously in the cooling models of magnetized neutron stars. By means of comparison with data, the study can give answers to many open questions about fundamental physics at the extreme conditions met in neutron stars.

Past experience in numerical simulations (fluid dynamics, MHD, diffusion problems, and/or other systems of PDEs) and fortran (or C++) programming skills are required. Previous knowledge of general neutron star physics would be convenient, although not strictly necessary.

The candidate must have the ability work in a team, as well as performing independent work and  he/she is expected to cooperate in the supervision of PhD students and to travel between Barcelona, Alicante and Amsterdam during the appointment.

The position is initially for two years, renewable for a third year depending on funds and performance, with a competitive salary and generous travel funds. The salary is set by Dutch labor law depending on seniority, including generous benefits, collective health insurance, 16 weeks paid maternity leave, childcare subsidies, pension, and about 35 days annual paid vacation.

Applications must include a 1) Curriculum Vitae, 2) a list of publications, and 3) a brief summary of previous and current research. Furthermore, applicants must also arrange for two reference letters to be provided directly by their authors.

We will start to shortlist the applicants on 2013 December 1st, until the position is filled. The starting date is expected to be around early 2014, but later starting dates are also possible. For further information, please contact Nanda Rea (n.rea@uva.nl).

fields.title: Two Faculty Positions in Exoplanetary Research and Instrumentation at UvA and SRON
fields.text:
Two Tenure-track positions for exoplanetary research and instrumentation at the Anton Pannekoek Institute for Astronomy of the University of Amsterdam (UvA) and at SRON Netherlands Institute for Space Research. The Anton Pannekoek Institute for Astronomy at the University of Amsterdam has a long tradition of excellence in astronomical research, including a strong program on star and planet formation. It is part of the Dutch Top Research School NOVA.

The UvA and SRON are seeking to fill two tenure-track positions in the field of exoplanetary research, in order to start a close collaboration in this area. In the context of a large reshaping of the research landscape in Amsterdam, the University of Amsterdam and the Free University are intensifying their collaboration in Natural Sciences, creating one of the largest concentrations in Europe. Research into exoplanets and the connections with System Earth will be a strong focus of research on the Science Park campus. In addition, SRON/Utrecht is planning to relocate from its current location in Utrecht to a new building in the Science Park in Amsterdam. In order to build a new area of joint research between SRON and the astronomy department of the universities in Amsterdam and other universities, we are looking for

1. An observational astronomer with strong abilities to work with existing ESO and other internationally competitive instrumentation on the detection and in particular characterization of exoplanets. The candidate will have an exceptionally strong research program in this area and should be able to connect both to the research on protoplanetary disks and planet formation at the University of Amsterdam and to instrumentation efforts at SRON.

2. A planetary atmosphere modelling expert with strong abilities for the analysis and modelling of exoplanet observations. The candidate is expected to build up strong ties with international instrumentation teams in the field of the conception and scientific optimization of new ground based and in particular space based instrumentation.

Both candidates are required to have a PhD in (astro)physics and should have proven capabilities to build up a research group of internationally outstanding level. Scientists at both institutions have access to national funding lines, e.g. the "Vernieuwings Impuls" at the Dutch research organization NWO, as well as European funding lines like ERC grants and FP7 programs and networks.

The selected candidates will be offered a tenure track appointment at UvA or SRON. The salary will be at assistant/associate professor equivalent levels based primarily on previous experience.

Letters of application (including resume, research and teaching statements, publication list highlighting five characteristic ones) and (separately) three letters of reference should be sent to secr-astro-science@uva.nl before 15 May 2014. Applications will continue to be considered until the position is filled.

Comprehensive benefits include paid vacation, sick leave, 13th month, disability insurance, maternity and parental leave, affordable health insurance, and retirement benefits.

fields.title: Tenure-Track Faculty Position in Radio Astronomy  at UvA and ASTRON
fields.text:
The Astronomy Group of ASTRON, the Netherlands Institute for Radio Astronomy in Dwingeloo (NL, www.astron.nl) and the Anton Pannekoek Institute for Astronomy of the University of Amsterdam (www.astro.uva.nl) invite applications for a tenure-track position shared between these two institutes. We are looking for enthusiastic candidates with at least a PhD in astronomy, astrophysics or a related discipline, demonstrated ability for ground-breaking research, an excellent publication record and the potential to secure external funding as well as a number of years work experience as a postdoc. Preference will be given to candidates with interest and expertise in observational radio astronomy and on topics of common interest for the two institutes, especially in high-energy and transient radio sources.

The selected candidate is expected to provide a liaison role and strengthen the - already many - collaborations between the two groups, especially towards a role in LOFAR and SKA development and science, spending approximately equal time at both institutes. They are also expected to provide valuable input into the various astronomical and technical programs at ASTRON and the Anton Pannekoek Institute, and will be included in the teaching programme at the University of Amsterdam.

ASTRON and the Anton Pannekoek Institute offer a vibrant, international and academic research environment with access to world-class observational facilities. ASTRON developed LOFAR and is a major partner in the operation of the International LOFAR Telescope (ILT). ASTRON also operates the Westerbork Synthesis Radio Telescope (WSRT), and is a leading institute in the development of the SKA. The Anton Pannekoek Institute is part of the Netherlands Research School for Astronomy (NOVA), and conducts research and teaching in astronomy at the highest level worldwide. Its particular expertises are in exoplanetary and stellar astrophysics, and in the extreme astrophysics of neutron stars and black holes, and astroparticle physics. It is part of the vibrant and still growing natural science cluster at Science Park Amsterdam, with excellent experimental and computing facilities.

Letters of application (including resume, research and teaching statements, publication list highlighting five characteristic ones), plus 3 letters of reference should be sent to personnel@astron.nl before 1 August 2014, referring to vacancy number 2014-03-022. fields.title: Two Postdoctoral positions in Astroparticle Physics
fields.text:
The Netherlands Organization for Scientific Research (NWO) has just launched a new research initiative in Astroparticle Physics, with a particular focus on understanding relativistic compact objects using a combined theoretical and multi-messenger approach.  Four interconnected projects will be conducted within different national research groups as detailed below, with topics reflecting Dutch Astronomy and Particle Physics expertise in the areas of cosmic rays, gamma-rays and gravitational waves.  The projects will be coordinated within the national Astroparticle Physics framework, and successful candidates will have significant interactions with their counterparts at other universities, and the Dutch Astroparticle Physics community, via frequent collaboration and yearly national meetings.

As part of this program, two postdoctoral research positions (up to 3 yrs, conditional on performance) are available at the University of Amsterdam, within the API/GRAPPA institutes:

1) Experimental TeV Gamma-ray Astronomy: The successful candidate will be an excellent experimentalist ready to lead the construction of two cameras for the small-size telescopes (SSTs) of CTA (http://www.cta-observatory.org). These two cameras will be mounted on two dual-mirror optics SSTs, produced within a UK-French-Japanese-German-Dutch sub-consortium of CTA.  Applicants should have an interest in instrumentation, and the ambition to lead the Dutch camera effort, and ideally have experience with fast electronics in particle physics or astroparticle physics experiments. Contributions to the first very-high-energy gamma-ray data analyses of the CTA-SST prototypes are expected at 20% of the candidate's time.  There is ample opportunity to participate in directing PhD and MSc student projects.   Supervisor: D. Berge (Amsterdam), Collaborators: A. van den Berg (KVI/Groningen), J. Hörandel (RU Nijmegen), S. Markoff (Amsterdam), O. Scholten (KVI/Groningen), L. Venema (ASTRON & U Leiden), J. Vink (Amsterdam).  The position will involve frequent travel to, and extensive collaboration with, the Universities of Groningen and Nijmegen. Contact:  d.berge@uva.nl

2) Theoretical:  The successful candidate will use a mix of semi-analytical methods and Particle-in-Cell techniques to study the conditions for turbulence, plasma instabilities and shock acceleration specifically for Galactic XRBs, with the goal of producing more self-consistent models to predict cosmic ray and TeV gamma-ray fluxes.  Interest and some experience in coding and theoretical astrophysics are required, experience in semi-analytical and/or numerical MHD/astrophysics or PIC codes a definite plus.  Position is based in Amsterdam, but travel to visit collaborators is encouraged.  Supervisors: S. Markoff (Amsterdam) and B. Achterberg (RU Nijmegen).  Collaborators: A. Boyarsky (Leiden), D. Berge (Amsterdam), D. Caprioli (Princeton), M. Dieckmann (Linkoeping), A. Marcowith (Montpellier), J. Vink (Amsterdam).  Contact:  s.b.markoff@uva.nl

Interested applicants should send a CV, list of publications and a brief (1 page) statement of relevant research experience and interests, plus the names and email addresses of three references, directly to the contact person listed above.  Complete applications received by 1 November 2014 will be given priority, though applications will be considered until positions are filled.  Candidates must have their PhDs by the start date and within the last three years (minus parental leave etc.).  The appointments will ideally begin by March 2015, but a starting date no later than September 2015 may be negotiated.  Females and minorities are especially encouraged to apply.

The Anton Pannekoek Institute for Astronomy (API) is a lively research institutes with about a dozen each of faculty and postdocs, and ~25 each of PhD and Masters students (see http://www.astro.uva.nl).   Gravitation and Astroparticle Physics Amsterdam (GRAPPA) is a new Astroparticle Physics initiative involving API, as well as the Institute for Theoretical Physics Amsterdam (ITFA) and Institute for High Energy Physics (IHEF) at the University of Amsterdam, with seven full time faculty and many associated faculty, postdocs and students (see http://grappa.science.uva.nl).   About half of our researchers are foreign and English is the lingua franca in the Science Faculy of the University of Amsterdam.    The Science Faculty of the University of Amsterdam is located about a 20 minute bicycle ride or an 8 minute direct train ride from the downtown main train station,  at the Amsterdam Science Park, also the informatics/computing technology center of the Netherlands.   Amsterdam was recently ranked the 2nd most 'liveable' city in the world by the EIU.

fields.title: Postdoctoral researcher in pulsar astronomy (f/m)
fields.text:
We are looking for an enthusiastic and talented researcher with radio astronomy, multi-wavelength transient/pulsar search, and/or strong computational experience to work as a:

Postdoctoral researcher in pulsar astronomy (f/m)

Job description:

The successful candidate will be a key member of a team that is supported by a Netherlands Foundation for Scientific Research (NWO) Vidi Fellowship (PI Hessels). Depending on the candidate’s previous experience, they will work on a combination of pulsar timing/searching experiments, as well as develop new algorithms for these. The primary source of data will be the new Low-Frequency Array (LOFAR). It is expected that the postdoc will further develop their strong scientific, analytical and technical skills, in order to be well placed to play an important role in the next generation of cutting-edge radio astronomical instrumentation, including MeerKAT, ASKAP, and the SKA.

As a postdoctoral researcher you will work at the University of Amsterdam’s Anton Pannekoek Astronomical Institute and also part time at ASTRON (Netherlands institute for Radio Astronomy). The successful candidate will be based at the University of Amsterdam and will be expected to make regular (once per 2 week) visits to ASTRON in Dwingeloo (1.5hr north of Amsterdam) as well as working regularly in Amsterdam.

The ASTRON / University of Amsterdam Pulsar Group is comprised of four faculty members (Dr. A.T. Deller, Dr. G.H. Janssen, Dr. J.W.T. Hessels, and Dr. A.G.J. van Leeuwen) as well as ten postdocs and PhD students. It is a very lively scientific environment with close access to instruments (the LOFAR and Westerbork telescopes) and other world-class researchers working in radio and/or high-energy astrophysics. The group has a broad set of interests and achievements, including wide-field fast transient and pulsar searches (LOFAR/APERTIF/GBT/Arecibo), studying pulsar phenomenology at multiple wavelengths, precision astronometry, and testing fundamental physics through pulsar timing.

 

Job requirements:

• a PhD degree in astronomy, astrophysics, or a related discipline;

• experience in radio astronomy and/or multi-wavelength transient search techniques;

• good oral and written communications skills;

• publication experience in refereed scientific journal and conference papers;

• strong experience with instrumentation and/or software development is also highly valued;

• good command of English (written and spoken).

 

Offer:

• we offer a contract for two years plus a one year extension, pending good performance;

• in addition to a pleasant and stimulating work environment, we offer a good package of benefits like a pension plan and group discounts on personal insurances;

• we offer flexible conditions of employment, tailored to your personal situation;

• we offer generous relocation expenses and support with finding accommodation;

• we offer excellent computational facilities and travel support

 

The organizations:

The Anton Pannekoek Institute for Astronomy (University of Amsterdam) is located in the Amsterdam Science Park, amidst the majority of the university’s scientific departments and also with close contact to other national research institutes like the national computing facility SURFsara (www.surfsara.nl) and the national sub-atomic physics institute NIKHEF (www.nikhef.nl). The Anton Pannekoek Institute (API) is part of the Netherlands Research School for Astronomy (NOVA), and conducts research and teaching in astronomy at the highest level worldwide. Its particular expertises are in exoplanetary and stellar astrophysics, and in the extreme astrophysics of neutron stars and black holes, and astroparticle physics.

Publication date: 29 July 2014

ASTRON, the Netherlands Institute for Radio Astronomy, is located just outside the town of Dwingeloo in the province of Drenthe. Its mission is to make discoveries in radio astronomy happen via the development of novel and innovative technologies, the operation of world-class radio astronomy facilities and the pursuit of fundamental astronomical research.

ASTRON’s Astronomy Group offers a scientifically rich environment with strong ties to technical development in the domain of radio astronomy both within the institute and internationally. ASTRON astronomers are active in many frontline research areas: galaxy structure and evolution, the interstellar and intergalactic medium, pulsars and compact objects, the transient radio sky, AGN evolution, studies of the magnetic universe, large radio continuum and HI surveys, deep fields, and gravitational lensing. They are also heavily involved in the operation and use of LOFAR and involved in preparing for the wide-field astronomy that will be made possible with instruments like APERTIF, which will be installed on the WSRT in the very near future. ASTRON astronomers are also involved in preparations for the SKA and participate in SKA precursor projects. Other front-line research facilities available to astronomers resident in the Netherlands include ESO, ALMA, and the ING telescopes.
